title: Sparsely totient number
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, a sparsely totient number is a certain kind of <a href="natural%20number">natural number</a>. A natural number, "n", is sparsely totient if for all "m" > "n",
where formula_2 is <a href="Euler%27s%20totient%20function">Euler's totient function</a>. The first few sparsely totient numbers are:
<a href="2%20%28number%29">2</a>, <a href="6%20%28number%29">6</a>, <a href="12%20%28number%29">12</a>, <a href="18%20%28number%29">18</a>, <a href="30%20%28number%29">30</a>, <a href="42%20%28number%29">42</a>, <a href="60%20%28number%29">60</a>, <a href="66%20%28number%29">66</a>, <a href="90%20%28number%29">90</a>, <a href="120%20%28number%29">120</a>, <a href="126%20%28number%29">126</a>, <a href="150%20%28number%29">150</a>, <a href="210%20%28number%29">210</a>, <a href="240%20%28number%29">240</a>, <a href="270%20%28number%29">270</a>, <a href="330%20%28number%29">330</a>, <a href="420%20%28number%29">420</a>, 462, 510, 630, 660, 690, 840, 870, 1050, 1260, 1320, 1470, 1680, 1890, 2310, 2730, 2940, 3150, 3570, 3990, 4620, 4830, 5460, 5610, 5670, 6090, 6930, 7140, 7350, 8190, 9240, 9660, 9870, ... .
The concept was introduced by <a href="David%20Masser">David Masser</a> and <a href="Peter%20Man-Kit%20Shiu">Peter Man-Kit Shiu</a> in 1986. As they showed, every <a href="primorial">primorial</a> is sparsely totient.
